Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Reference to hardship due to earlier wars.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Granted tax-immunity from customs-dues for fruit and livestock.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Changed the tax regime for various crops (grain, pulses, millet, seame, among others) to a tithe.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Granted tax-immunity for all other portions of grain.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
All citizens and non-citizens to participate in the sacrifices.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios
Penalty of 1,000 drachmas for priests who do not carry out the sacrifices in Ptolemaios' honour.
Honorific decree for the dynast Ptolemaios

Honorifc decree for Hermogenes by an unknown city granting him citizenship

Mention of income of the last five years.
Waiver of tax on chortos and achyra.
Billeting obligations waived for ten years.
Regulation on the tax on craftsmen imposed on foreign craftsmen.
Honorific decree for Eumenes II and his family for a victory over the Galatians
Eumenes II's campaign against Prousias II and Ortiagon.
Honorific decree for Eumenes II and his family for a victory over the Galatians
Honorific decree for Eumenes II and his family for a victory over the Galatians
Sacrifice and prayer for Eumenes' continuing victory.
Honorific decree for Eumenes II and his family for a victory over the Galatians
Sacrifices to commemorate victory of Eumenes.
Honorific decree for Eumenes II and his family for a victory over the Galatians
Dedication of a grove and temenos(?) to Athena Nikephoros.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
Land that the Kardakians had bought from Ptolemaios the dynast.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
The Kardakians allowed to possess the land they had bought from Ptolemaios.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
They are allowed to keep the price at which they had bought it, and are exempt from paying for the land (presumably Eumenes was expecting another payment having recently acquired the territory).
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
Exemption from the poll-tax for two years, which is defined as 4 Rhodian drachmas and an obol.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
Exemption from tax for those whom they bring in from outside the kingdom for three years, and two years for thos who return having left earlier.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
The king grants permission to build a fort, but that the Kardakians need to pay for it themselves.
Letter of Eumenes II to Artemidoros granting tax-immunity to the Kardakes
He will however pay for a technician.

List of names and plots of land, may record the allocation of land-plots to the new settlement at Balboura.

Provisions for neither Rome nor Kibyra to support their enemies with weapons or money.

Dedication of an altar to Zeus Soter
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
A foundation towards sacrifices and banquest in perpetuity.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Provisions for an annual sacrificial feast, at which portions will be given to Symmasis and his descendants.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Money to be lent out at interest under the name of the money of Symmasis.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Penalty of 1,000 drachmas consecrated to Helios if the money is not lent out, with half going to the informer. Drachmas indicated by a two-bar sign.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Penalty of twice the amount concerned if the money is diverted to any other purpose.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
The construction of a tomb is implied by the penalties for its misuse.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Symmasis, administered by the koinon of the metal-workers
Penalty of 100 drachmas if anyone else is buried in the tomb. Drachmas indicated by a two-bar sign.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Pokomas
A foundation towards sacrifices and banquest in perpetuity.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Pokomas
Provisions for an annual sacrificial feast, and for portions to be given to Pokomas and his descendants.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Pokomas
Penalty for not handing money over to the brabeutai of half the amount that should have been given.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Pokomas
The brabeutai to spend 10 drachmas on a drinking vessel, a kothon.
Decree concerning the funerary foundation of Pokomas
Penalty of 1,000 drachmas for misuse of the funds.
Fragments of an honorific statue-base inscription for a major benefactor?
Numerous gifts towards games, feasts, gladiatorial fights?
Fragments of an honorific statue-base inscription for a major benefactor?
Numerous gifts towards feasts, and handouts of money (argurikas epidoseis)?
Fragments of an honorific statue-base inscription for a major benefactor?
Gave 300,000 drachmas to several Lykian cities.
Fragments of an honorific statue-base inscription for a major benefactor?
Fragments of an honorific statue-base inscription for a major benefactor?
Distribution of drachma-sums to xenokritai, councillors, and archostatai.
Funerary inscription for Telesias and his family
A fine of a silver talent for opening the tomb unlawfully.
Funerary inscription of Id[---] and Pixodaros
A fine of unknown amount for opening the tomb unlawfully.
A fine of 3,000 drachmas payable both to the descendant of Hermoas and the city for anyone else who buries a body in the tomb.

The honorand served as sitones, demarchos, and priest of Apollo.
Towards the reception of the people, probably with feasts and sacrifices.

The Kaunian king to receive three half-minas, i.e. 1.5 minas, a year.

Those who are freed are to pay 2 drachmas to the priest.

Produce from the estates inscribed on the stele to be sacrificed each month.
